reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as 狩り, but since it follows another word, it gets rendaku-ed. Here is a mnemonic to help with remembering the rendaku.

Hunting can be <reading>girly</reading> (がり), if you dress up like a girly hunter.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
Even if she is your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary>, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! <reading>Baa!</reading> (ばあ).
The reading of 嬢 is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!
The reading comes from the word 陰. <vocabulary>Thanks to</vocabulary> that other vocab word, you can read this one!
The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.
したくちびる just combines the kun'yomi vocab reading for 下 and the kun'yomi reading you learned with the kanji for 唇.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.

The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

So how does Italy attain its <vocabulary>flamboyance</vocabulary>? Because it embodies <reading>Da</reading>n<reading>te</reading>’s (だて) bold essence—vibrant, captivating, and <vocabulary>chic</vocabulary> in every way. In Italy, Dante's influence is a living testament to flamboyant elegance.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on <vocabulary>makeup</vocabulary>. They finish putting it on, and then you say "<reading>K, show</reading> (けしょう) me!"
The readings come from the words 取る and 分ける. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some <vocabulary>pathetic</vocabulary> person who lost their home. They may be <vocabulary>pitiful</vocabulary> but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "<reading>Why</reading> (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.
You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel <vocabulary>pity</vocabulary> for and just think... <reading>aww</reading> (あわ), that's really pathetic.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you climb to the top of the <vocabulary>peak</vocabulary>, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is <reading>竹</reading> (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji 川 doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a <vocabulary>comic haiku</vocabulary>, think of something hilarious... like a <reading>cen</reading>taur (せん), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.
The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Imagine trying <vocabulary>to carve something</vocabulary> using a <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be <reading>you, Ra</reading> (うら). You and your dumb sun.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
What do you hate and detest more than anything? <reading>肉</reading> (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.
I'm going <vocabulary>to rest</vocabulary> and play some <reading>Ico</reading> (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.
Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to fan</vocabulary> yourself with an <reading>青</reading> (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the rendaku.

Out of the <vocabulary>front door</vocabulary> <reading>jump</reading>s (飛び) <reading>Ra</reading> (ら). Every morning he can't wait to burst forth from the front door to soak in the Sun. He is the Egyptian sun god, after all.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading used for 挿絵 is an exceptional one. Instead of そう it's さし. When you think of a <vocabulary>book illustration</vocabulary>, think of an illustration of a <reading>sash</reading>. Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes.

絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

Where is the <vocabulary>palm of one's hand</vocabulary>? It's on your <reading>手のhere</reading> (てのひら). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was."

Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

You really don’t want your knee <vocabulary>to be grazed</vocabulary>. If it happens, you are gonna <reading>sue</reading> (す). But the <reading>cos</reading>t (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place!

Depending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.
The <kanji>willow</kanji> you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's <reading>yah naggy</reading> <vocabulary>weeping willow</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, <reading>as a moo</reading> (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.
The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as 湿る.

<vocabulary>To drip</vocabulary> drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "<reading>sh*t, ta-ta</reading> (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.
The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help:

You sit eating <vocabulary>senbei</vocabulary> next to a <reading>bay</reading> (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.
The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!
The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is <vocabulary>tatami mat</vocabulary>. The たたみ part, specifically.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as 眺める.
The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're walking through that big fat <vocabulary>gravel</vocabulary>, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... <reading>ja</reading>guar (じゃ)! Run!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 稼ぐ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you <reading>never never</reading> want to touch something <vocabulary>sticky</vocabulary>.
Will I give up? I'll <reading>never</reading> (ねば) give up! I'll also never unstick from you.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know <vocabulary>paper money</vocabulary> is made of <reading>shee</reading>p (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading here is a bit weird. It's like the words 裸 (はだか) and 足 (あし) were smushed together into one word. The 裸 becomes はだ and the 足 becomes し. You can think of it this way: You were <vocabulary>barefoot</vocabulary> too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you <reading>had ashi</reading> (はだし) at one point in the past.

The reading for this is unfortunately a bit of an exception. 親 uses the kun'yomi おや, and 父 uses the じ reading which you learned with 叔父. You've learned all these readings before, so as long as you remember them, you're good to go. If you don't, check out the mnemonics for these readings on their vocabularies' pages!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

The reading of 雑 is different from what you've learned. Instead of ざつ it's ぞう. Just imagine using this <vocabulary>dust cloth</vocabulary> to wipe down a <reading>象</reading> (ぞう). Its trunk is particularly dusty.

Imagine you're <reading>co-bo</reading>iling (こぼ) water with someone. With the two of you co-boiling, the water is boiling pretty hard. Watch out, though — you're about <reading>to spill</reading> the hot water everywhere!
The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.
